title-group.article-title: Passive and active nonlinear fault-tolerant control of a quadrotor unmanned aerial vehicle based on the sliding mode control technique

author-notes.corresp: Youmin Zhang, Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, Concordia University, 1455 de Maisonneuve Blvd, Montreal, Quebec H3G 1M8, Canada. Email: ymzhang@encs.concordia.ca

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue on advanced control of aerospace vehicles

abstract.p: In this paper, an augmented sliding mode-based fault-tolerant control is designed theoretically, implemented practically and tested experimentally in a quadrotor unmanned aerial vehicle testbed under propeller damage and actuator fault conditions for tracking control. In view of the significant feature of robustness inherent to the sliding mode control technique, the developed sliding mode-based fault-tolerant control strategies have been designed and implemented in the two currently and widely used types of fault-tolerant control strategy, i.e. passive and active, with the intention to investigate and compare the advantages, disadvantages and application considerations and limitations of these two different fault-tolerant control strategies in the tracking control problem of a quadrotor unmanned aerial vehicle application. Therefore, these two types of controller have been carried out in both theory and practice with and without the presence of faults. Both theoretical and experimental analyses demonstrated the effectiveness of the two sliding mode-based fault-tolerant control strategies in the application to the quadrotor unmanned aerial vehicle under a small level of actuator faults or damage. Detailed comparisons are also provided in the paper to demonstrate the capabilities, advantages and disadvantages of the two types of fault-tolerant tracking controller under different flight conditions in the presence of actuator faults and propeller damage.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Early research has shown many advanced control design techniques for fault-tolerant control systems (FTCSs).1–3 A recent comprehensive survey on FTCSs presented by Zhang and Jiang4 highlights the classification of fault-tolerant control (FTC) as passive fault-tolerant control (PFTC) and active/reconfigurable fault-tolerant control (AFTC) which combines a fault detection and diagnosis (FDD) scheme. Safety, reliability and reconfigurability analyses have also been outlined by those authors for making a link between the currently individual research work on control engineering and safety engineering. Some key points in FTCSs were also summarized in an early review paper2 for control design methods developed up to 1997. As a few examples for FTC research and development, Fekih and Pilla5 presented a passive FTC methodology using a sliding surface and Lyapunov function to eliminate the pre-specified faults for an F-18 aircraft model. The results showed the effectiveness of the control design. Zhang and Jiang6 presented an integrated design procedure for fault detection, diagnosis and reconfigurable control. A two-stage adaptive Kalman filter was used in fault detection and diagnosis. The reconfigurable feedback and feedforward controllers were developed in detail as well. Milhim et al.7 designed a gain scheduling-based proportional–integral–derivative (GS-PID) controller for FTC of a quadrotor unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) under simulation environment. The idea of GS-PID has recently been further implemented and experimentally tested in a quadrotor helicopter UAV by Sadeghzadeh et al.,8 with three-dimensional trajectory tracking capability in the presence of actuator faults.

As an effective and well-known robust control technique, sliding mode control (SMC) has been widely used to improve the stability, performance and robustness of control systems in the presence of uncertainties. Despite the significant property and advantage of the robustness inherent to SMC, conventional SMC cannot handle fault-induced system dynamic changes and uncertainties effectively. Therefore, there is an urgent need to investigate, develop and in particular test experimentally the SMC-based control strategies for FTC applications to further exploit the advantages of SMC and to enhance the robustness of the overall control system in handling faults occurring in the system. Existing studies have shown that SMC-based FTC can greatly improve the stability and robustness of the system under fault conditions. Some of the initial works on using SMC for fault-tolerant/reconfigurable control can be attributed as follows. Shtessel et al.9 addressed a dual-timescale aircraft flight control problem via continuous SMC. The reconfigurable sliding-mode flight control technique was applied to a nonlinear flight dynamics model of an F-16 aircraft with computer simulations. Hess and Wells10 applied SMC to the design of a flight control system capable of operating with limited bandwidth actuators and in the presence of significant damage to the airframe and/or control actuators. The developed technique was exercised on a pitch-axis controller for a simple short-period model of the high angle of attack F-18 vehicle also via computer simulation. Alwi and Edwards11 designed a sliding mode-based FTC for a civilian fixed-wing aircraft, the Boeing 747. The elevator failure was simulated and the simulation results showed satisfactory performance of the controller. Alwi and Edwards12 proposed another method using a sliding mode scheme with control allocation for FTC of the Boeing 747. With on-line control allocation, an active FTC was designed and illustrated using the sliding mode algorithm. Most recently, a fault-tolerant attitude tracking control scheme was developed for a flexible spacecraft with the fault of partial loss of actuator effectiveness by Xiao et al.13 A simulation example of a flexible spacecraft was given to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed controller.

SMC has also been used in other dynamic systems as a robust controller. In Wu et al.,14,15 using an integral sliding surface and along with the strict linear matrix inequality (LMI), SMC and state estimation were designed to enhance the robustness of stochastic hybrid systems and Markovian jump singular systems, respectively. The system states can also be predicted well by the method proposed. Another sliding mode-based observer was introduced and investigated by the same authors16,17 that can reduce the risk of having inaccurate state variables which could cause the controller to become unstable.

However, all of the above existing works on FTC were evaluated only by simulation and also with fixed-wing type of aircraft or spacecraft. Therefore, the main motivation and contribution of the present paper was to develop new designs of sliding mode-based FTC with experimental validation on an available physical testbed18 of a quadrotor UAV (known as Qball-X4), which has been developed recently through collaboration between Concordia University and a Canadian-based industrial partner (Quanser Inc.) with financial support from the NSERC (Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada) through a Strategic Project Grant (SPG) led by Concordia University.

The paper is divided into the following sections. The Qball-X4 system model is introduced first. Next, the sliding mode-based active fault-tolerant controller and the passive fault-tolerant controller are designed based on an augmented sliding surface technique and by combining integral action in the SMC design. Simulation results are then shown. The experimental setup of the Qball-X4 system and the experimental flight testing results and comparisons are given thereafter. Finally, conclusions are drawn.

sec.title: SMC-based PFTC
sec.p: The simulations have been carried out under the situation of 15% loss of the fourth propeller in the control effectiveness. The fault is assumed to occur at 20 s for all testing scenarios considered in the paper. The design task is to track a square trajectory for tracking control under both fault-free and faulty conditions. The results shown in Figures 3 to 5 prove that the designed PFTC controller has the ability of handling 15% loss as the actuator fault. After occurrence of the fault, it is expected that the original trajectory tracking is still being maintained without significant degradation of the tracking performance.

sec.p: As shown in Figure 3, good tracking performance has been achieved and the desired path along all three axes, x, y and z, has been well followed, which proves that the augmented SMC control system with an extra integral component is robust enough to maintain the stability and tracking performance of the quadrotor UAV system in the presence of actuator fault.

sec.title: SMC-based AFTC
sec.p: The task in this case is still to track the same square trajectory as used in the PFTC case and with the same fault, for easy comparison of performance between PFTC and AFTC. Since the system is now in AFTC mode, there are two separate controllers in use: one for normal (fault-free) flight, the other for faulty conditions. The first controller is from equation (14) for flight conditions before occurrence of the fault and the second one is from equation (36) for flight conditions after occurrence of the fault. The results show that the performance of the tracking is also excellent (Figure 6). Based on intuition, if an actuator fault occurs, the controller normally pushes more on the actuator with failure to maintain the balance. However, from Figures 4 and 5, it can be seen that the PFTC controller responds insignificantly to the fault, and the system is stabilized only by the sliding mode controller with its inherent robustness. From Figures 7 and 8 it can be seen that the AFTC controller clearly exerts more control effort on the system in the presence of a fault. Therefore, the AFTC actions for compensating the faults are stronger or more aggressive than PFTC, and faster and better tracking performance can normally be achieved, with relevant larger control signal re-adjustments, as shown in Figures 7 and 8.

sec.title: Description of the experimental setup
sec.p: The experimental tests have been carried out in the Qball-X4 quadrotor helicopter testbed available at the Networked Autonomous Vehicles (NAV) lab of Concordia University. The testbed includes six cameras as the indoors global positioning system for providing the position of the Qball-X4 during the flight in real time, a joystick as the safety control and a desktop computer as the ground control station. The reason for the name ‘Qball-X4’ is because of the ball-shaped protection cage surrounding the quadrotor to protect the four propellers and also the person who is using the Qball-X4 for flight tests. The four propellers are lined up orthogonally as shown in Figure 1. The black-box at the centre has all the control hardware devices that send control signals to control the attitude and motion of the Qball-X4 during flight, to generate different pulses to each rotor for pitch, roll and yaw commands with the control algorithm implemented in software format in the on-board Gumstix single-chip microcomputer (control device).

For the system, not only are there inertial sensors on the HiQ board which is located inside the black-box, but also vision sensors of the OptiTrack camera system from Natural Point, Inc.21 are in use. Hence, the positions of Qball-X4 can be indicated by the feedback from a set of high-precision cameras mounted on the ceiling. The direct global positions can be easily attained, and a direct x–y–z position control becomes possible as well. If necessary, the controller of the Qball-X4 system can then be separated into two independent parts: altitude controller and attitude controller.

In order to mimic faulty situations to test the stability and performance of the developed FTCS, there is an extra device used for generating faults during real-time flight. Figure 9 shows the device used to brake the propeller blade during flight to mimic the occurrence of propeller damage in real flight situations. Thus, actuator faults or propeller damage can be generated during flight with the testbed. The behaviours of PFTC and AFTC can then be tested based on this testbed.

caption.p: The mechanism for injecting propeller damage during a flight.

sec.p: The overall process of controlling the Qball-X4 is achieved through wireless communication. When all the sensor measurements of the Qball-X4 are sent back to the ground station through Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol wireless connection, the controller on the ground station will start to generate the control inputs and these inputs will be sent to the Qball-X4 on-board system. The data transmission process is then complete, and the Qball-X4 will fly autonomously with the control and guidance law designed.

sec.title: Results of the SMC-based PFTC
sec.p: Using the setup discussed above, the PFTC controller can be implemented and tested. Figures 10 to 13 show the performance of the Qball-X4 during a real flight under the lab environment using the SMC-based PFTC. The task is still to track the square trajectory as in the simulation case. However, considering the size of the lab and the coverage area of the OptiTrack camera system, the desired square trajectory has been reduced to a smaller area of 1.5 m×1.5 m.

sec.p: The above experimental testing results show that the test was successful, except for a small disturbance at about 60 s as can be seen from Figure 13. This was caused by the camera system due to some random dropout of communication messages and delays in the wireless communication between the Qball-X4’s on-board control device and the ground station computer for transferring real-time position information of the Qball-X4 for feedback. The robustness of PFTC is a bit weak after the fault occurrence. A very small deviation in position in the z direction induced by the fault occurrence at 20 s can be observed in Figure 13, but with even less effect compared with the communication faults. Such a result also shows the robustness and good performance of the developed SMC-based PFTC strategy against both actuator and communication faults, although the controller was not designed especially for handling problems related to wireless communication.

sec.title: Results of the SMC-based AFTC
sec.p: Based on the same experimental setup, the AFTC system has also been tested successfully and the results are shown in Figures 14 to 17. The robustness of the AFTC is proved to be stronger based on the comparison of Figure 13 (PFTC) and Figure 17 (AFTC). In the same environment, AFTC is more robust than PFTC in handling extra disturbances.

sec.p: However, it should be noticed that the advantages of the AFTC strategy are not completed demonstrated in the above experimental tests because there is a limit of small magnitude of fault (15%) simulated/injected owing to a hardware redundancy limitation of the quadrotor helicopter configuration. Larger size of faults will make the quadrotor become uncontrollable in this initial design of such a quadrotor helicopter. To overcome the problem, modification of the existing Qball-X4 to a new Qball-X8, with eight propellers, is under development at the NAV lab. For interested readers, videos of the above flight testing results are available at http://users.encs.concordia.ca/~ymzhang/UAVs.htm.

sec.title: Comparisons
sec.p: Based on the simulation and experimental flight testing results shown in the previous sections, it can be seen that both SMC-based PFTC and SMC-based AFTC worked properly on the Qball-X4 system. However, if there are extra disturbances other than the faults, PFTC is more vulnerable to be affected than AFTC. Some numerical comparisons listed in Tables 1 to 3 are used to further demonstrate the difference between these two techniques. In theory, PFTC has a trade-off for both faulty situation and fault-free situation. Hence, the performance of PTFC is supposed to be imperfect under each situation, which has been proved by the experimental testing results. If there are extra or larger disturbances, the control system will be affected easily. However, AFTC can solve this problem by implementing two (or more) separate controllers for the system in fault-free and fault cases, respectively. Once the fault occurs, the control system will switch to the controller that is designed to overcome the effects of the fault and maintain the possible best/achievable performance. Thus, the performance of the control system under both situations can be optimized to the maximum. Based on the above experimental testing results, it can be seen that the average tracking performance of AFTC is better than that of PFTC. Such an improvement can be expected to be even greater for the AFTC strategy if more severe fault/damage occurs in the system. However, AFTC needs an FDD scheme to be embedded and combined with the AFTC algorithm. Such an FDD scheme is assumed to be available since the main focus of the current paper is to investigate, test and compare the PFTC and AFTC strategies under the SMC framework. Inclusion of an FDD scheme to form a truly active FTCS is one of our further works.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Based on the use of an augmented sliding surface technique and by combining integral action in the SMC design, new SMC-based passive and active FTC strategies have been developed and tested by flying a unique quadrotor UAV in the presence of actuator fault or propeller damage during flight. The tracking control performance has been tested and compared for the proposed SMC-based PFTC and AFTC algorithms. From all the simulation and experimental testing results presented in this paper, it can be seen that both the PFTC and AFTC designs have been proved appropriate for the quadrotor helicopter UAV testbed. Both controllers worked properly, while the AFTC showed better tracking performance even in the presence of the considered actuator fault and propeller damage. The limitations shown in the testing results are mainly because only a small level of faults is allowed to be injected on the quadrotor UAV due to the inherent low level of hardware redundancy. Therefore, the advantages of the AFTC strategy, which is more effective for cases with large or severe fault/damage, cannot be demonstrated effectively. As one future work, an FDD scheme will be combined and also tested with the proposed SMC-based AFTC strategy.
